qas.question: What was the first station to show programs in color?
When did the other two major British stations start color programming?
What types of programs were not shown on BBC Two?

answers.text: soap opera or standard news programming

qas.question: Who was the first controller of BBC2?
What kinds of programs did Attenborough favor?

plausible_answers.text: BBC Two became the first television channel in Europe to broadcast regularly in colour

qas.question: What did BBC One and ITV begin on 15 November 1967?
Who commissioned Horizon and The Ascent of Civilisation?

plausible_answers.text: range of programmes intended to be eclectic and diverse

qas.question: What does BBC Two air along with soap operas and standard news programming?

context: On 1 July 1967, <a0_0><b5_0>BBC Two<a0_0/> became the first television channel in Europe to broadcast regularly in colour<b5_0/>, using the West German PAL system that is still in use today although being gradually superseded by digital systems. (BBC One and ITV began <b6_0>625-line colour broadcasts<b6_0/> simultaneously on <a1_0>15 November 1969<a1_0/>). Unlike other terrestrial channels, BBC Two does not have <a2_0>soap opera or standard news programming<a2_0/>, but a <b8_0>range of programmes intended to be eclectic and diverse<b8_0/> (although if a programme has high audience ratings it is often eventually repositioned to BBC One). The different remit of BBC2 allowed its first controller, <a3_0><b7_0>Sir David Attenborough<b7_0/><a3_0/> to commission the first heavyweight <a4_0>documentaries<a4_0/> and documentary series such as Civilisation, The Ascent of Man and Horizon.
